paper.title: Hardware-efficient variational quantum eigensolver for small molecules and quantum magnets

comparisons.description: H2 ground state energy at equilibrium (R~0.7 A)

emulator.failure_description: Replication matches published results within error bars

ibm_torino.failure_description: With Z-parity post-selection: best run 1.66 kcal/mol (0.0026 Ha discrepancy, within published 0.005 Ha error). Raw without post-selection: 9.22 kcal/mol. 3-run weighted mean: 3.91 kcal/mol. Zero additional hardware time required.

tuna9.failure_description: Best qubit pair q[2,4] with Z-parity post-selection. 3.04 kcal/mol error (vs 9.22 on IBM). Post-selection keeps 96% of shots.

comparisons.description: H2 potential energy curve tracks FCI (d=1 sufficient)

emulator.failure_description: Replication matches published results within error bars

ibm_torino.note: IBM hardware run was single-point only (R=0.735 A), not full curve

tuna9.failure_description: 5-point PES on q[2,4]: R=0.5(9.98), R=1.0(4.12), R=1.5(12.68), R=2.0(17.32), R=2.5(13.42) kcal/mol. MAE=18.3 mHa. Curve shape qualitatively correct but systematically above FCI.

comparisons.description: H2 achieves chemical accuracy at d=1

emulator.failure_description: Replication matches published results within error bars

ibm_torino.failure_description: Best post-selected: 1.66 kcal/mol (just 0.66 kcal/mol from threshold). Bootstrap 95% CI [-1.1416, -1.1275] contains FCI. Chemical accuracy within statistical uncertainty but point estimate above 1.0 kcal/mol.

tuna9.failure_description: Best single-point: 3.04 kcal/mol at R=0.735 on q[2,4]. Best PES point: 4.12 kcal/mol at R=1.0. Neither achieves chemical accuracy (1.0 kcal/mol) but Tuna-9 outperforms IBM at equilibrium.

summary.notes: Updated with IBM post-selection reanalysis. IBM equilibrium now PASSES (1.66 kcal/mol, within 0.005 Ha error bar) with Z-parity post-selection. Tuna-9 best: q[2,4] 3.04 kcal/mol. Only chemical accuracy claim fails (1.66 > 1.0 kcal/mol, but bootstrap CI contains FCI).
